- @angular/router
- @angular/core

### Description
Detect when a lazy loaded module is being imported elsewhere (By mistake - in other word not only in the router path via `loadChildren`).  I think the "Confusion" around the following two issues stemmed from me accidentally importing a lazy loaded module into the main module.  [I wrote an article about it here.](https://medium.com/@ole.ersoy/angular-module-lazy-load-gotcha-9852d628257)  Something that is easy to do given the steep angular learning curve.

- https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27918
- https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/27920

### Describe the solution you'd like
If a lazy load module is imported anywhere except via the router path, throw an exception.  If this works well on stackblitz that would be a big plus.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
As can be seen in this SO issue imports of lazy loaded modules causes errors that it's easy to miss read.

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54030737/adding-id-to-guarded-component-path-causes-infinite-loop

I had several  other SO posts WRT this and it took a long time before someone diagnosed the import issue.

Issues.Title: CODEOWNERS global approvers plan
Issues.Body:
# Problem

`CODEOWNERS` maps each file to a group of approvers. Unfortunately, it can only have one group allowed per file - we cannot have groups of "global approvers" with the ability to approve changes across larger parts of the project.

We would like this capability as otherwise the review burden on large changes is too great. We cannot add individual users to every group as this creates review spam.

# Proposal

We already have a bot that monitors PR labels, posts PR statuses, etc. We will add this bot's user to every approval group in `CODEOWNERS`, making it a _de facto_ global approver.

The bot will be programmed with a configuration of global approvers and a list of review groups (e.g. `fw-core`) for which they are considered as global approvers.

For each PR, the bot will take action when all of the subsequent conditions are met:

1) A configured global approver (e.g. @kara) has approved the PR.

2) The same configured global approver has added the `PR state: global approval` label.

3) The PR has all _other_ approvals it needs (those not covered by the global approver(s).

When all 3 of these conditions are met, the bot itself will approve the PR. Because of its status as an approver for every group, this will enable the PR to merge.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "CODEOWNERS global approvers plan" (#28245)

# üöÄ feature request

Hello, 

### Description

It'll be great if we could **encapsulate all global styles** for the single Angular application. 

We are building PoC to cover **micro frontend** architecture ([PoC link](https://github.com/Marfusios/micro-frontend-gateway)), building blocks are Gateway app and Alpha/Beta micro frontends. Every micro frontend is lazy loaded dynamically at runtime, no static dependency at build time. 
Right now we are struggling with global vs local styles. 
The requirement is that every micro frontend is separated as much as possible. 
All styles from Beta micro frontend shoudn't interfere with Alpha's styles (when loaded in the Gateway together). 

One solution is to avoid global styles (empty `styles.scss`) and provide something like `global.scss` which is then included in the every component ([example](https://github.com/Marfusios/micro-frontend-beta/blob/master/src/entry/buttons-example/buttons-example.component.scss)). It works fine, styles are encapsulated, but it brings undesirable code duplication, every style is duplicated to every component. 
If we want to use some large design library, like Angular Material (DevExtreme, Clarity Design), it would bloat really fast. 

Do you have any idea, with current Angular features, how to do this?
* Alpha micro frontend will use DevExtreme design library
* Beta micro frontend will use Clarity design library
* after loading and displaying in the Gateway the styles won't interfere




### Describe the solution you'd like
For example, inside `angular.json`: 
```
            "encapsulatedStyles": [
              "src/global.scss"
            ]
```
Then it will use global shadowing for the whole application. 
Runtime example: 
`.my-class[_nghost-xxx]` 
`h1[_nghost-xxx]` 
where `xxx` could be randomly generated hash or name of the application.

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): fix styling context resolution for host bindings on containers
Issues.Body:
Previous to this change, the isStylingContext() function was improperly returning true
for LContainers because it used the presence of an array at index 2 to determine
whether it was a styling context. Unfortunately, LContainers also contain arrays at
index 2, so this would return a false positive. This led to other errors down the line
because we would treat nodes with containers as if they already had styling contexts
(even if they did not), so the proper initialization logic for styling contexts
was not run.

This commit fixes the isStylingContext() function to use LCONTAINER_LENGTH as a marker
rather than the presence of an array, which in turn fixes host bindings to styles on
nodes with containers.

Issues.Title: feat(cdkDragDrop): A way to block the origin list during a dragging action
Issues.Body:
#### Please describe the feature you would like to request.

A way to disable drag-and-drop on the origin list after a dragging has started and, afterward, restore its capability after the drop action

#### What is the use-case or motivation for this proposal?

I have a bunch of lists. One of them works as a source of resources (each element represents a resource type). The other lists work as the consumers of the resources.

In the source list, each element I show the total number of available resources of one type. I decrement this number whenever a resource is dragged and dropped on one of the consumer lists.

The problems is that I should be able to drag elements from/to the source. But I do not want to see a placeholder in either of these situations (despite the fact that I'd like to still be able to drag-and-drop elements from/to it):

    1 - when I am dropping an element to it, I do not want to show any placeholder
    2 - when I am dragging an element from it and hover the dragged element over it again, I do not want to see any placeholder (which seems to be the default behavior).

#### Is there anything else we should know?

I kind of worked it around by hiding the list while dragging (and showing a not draggable clone of it), and forbidding the dropping from other lists to it.

There are some possible similarities to #14539 (the item 2 above could be solved if I could set a placeholder to `none` in the drop list with some kind of `@Input()` or set a different placeholder depending on the origin of the element being dropped on it). The lists, in this use case, have different shapes.
